facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave against the order of the High Court of Kerala dated August 2, 1963, in Income-tax Reference Case No. 48/62 Agricultural.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal, by special leave, against the order of the High Court of Kerala dated August 2, 1963, in Income- tax Reference Case No. 48/62  Agricultural .

facts.text: The respondent is a company which owned a rubber estate purchased by it along with the plantation thereon.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a companypany which owned a rubber estate purchased by it along with the plantation thereon.

facts.text: The estate included rubber trees which, at the time of purchase, were in a condition of producing latex.

anchor.surface_text: The estate included rubber trees which, at the time of purchase, were in a companydition of producing latex.

facts.text: The rubber trees were sold by the company after they ceased to yield latex any further.

anchor.surface_text: The rubber trees were sold by the companypany after they ceased to yield latex any further.

facts.text: In computing its agricultural income for the accounting year ending February 28, 1959, relevant to the assessment year 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: In companyputing its agricultural income for the accounting year ending February 28, 1959, relevant to the assessment year 1959-60, for the purposes of the Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1950  XXII of 1950 ,

facts.text: The Assistant Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax included the sum of Rs. 8,532.50 representing the sale proceeds of rubber trees by order dated February 2, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: the Assistant Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax, by his order dated February 2, 1962, included the sum of Rs. 8,532.50 representing the sale proceeds of rubber trees which were cut down and sold after they became useless.

facts.text: Rubber trees were cut down and sold after they became useless.

anchor.surface_text: sale proceeds of rubber trees which were cut down and sold after they became useless.

facts.text: The respondent appealed to the Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales Tax, Quilon.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed to the Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales Tax, Quilon, objecting, inter alia, to the inclusion of the amount in companyputing its agricultural income.

facts.text: The Deputy Commissioner rejected the contention of the respondent by order dated November 30, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated November 30, 1960, the Deputy Commissioner rejected the companytention of the respondent.

facts.text: The respondent preferred a second appeal to the Agricultural Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Trivandrum.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon preferred a second appeal to the Agricultural Income-tax Appellate, Tribunal, Trivandrum.

facts.text: The Tribunal accepted the contention of the respondent and held that Rs. 8,532.50 was a capital receipt by order dated August 18, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated August 18, 1962, the Tribunal accepted the companytention of the respondent and held that the sum of Rs. 8,532.50 representing the sale proceeds of rubber trees cut down and sold after they had become useless was number taxable as income, but was merely a capital receipt.

facts.text: On the application of the appellant, the Tribunal stated a case to the Kerala High Court and referred two questions of law.

facts.text: The appellant obtained special leave to appeal to this court.

facts.text: The appellant contends that Rs. 8,532.50 was a revenue receipt to be included in agricultural income.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytention mainly is that the sum of Rs. 8,532.50 was in the nature of a revenue receipt and had to be included in companyputing the agricultural income.

by special leave against the order of the High Court of Kerala dated August 2, 1963, in Income- tax Reference Case No. 48/62  Agricultural . The facts leading to this appeal may be briefly stated.

special leave to appeal to this court. The appellants contention mainly is that the sum of Rs. 8,532.50 was in the nature of a revenue receipt and had to be included in computing the agricultural income.

Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1950  XXII of 1950 , the Assistant Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax, by his order dated February 2, 1962, included the sum of Rs. 8,532.50 representing the sale proceeds of rubber trees which were cut down and sold after they became useless.

concepts.unlisted_description: Governing statute for assessment of agricultural income

anchor.surface_text: section 2 a  of the Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1950  XXII of 1950 , hereinafter called the Act, defines agricultural income. Agricultural income means -  1  any rent or revenue derived from land which is used for agricultural purposes  2  any income derived form such land in the State by - agriculture,

concepts.interpretation: The definition does not include proceeds from the sale of rubber trees in an estate which were utilised for the purpose of deriving income in the shape of latex.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ere utilised for the purpose of deriving income in the shape of latex. There was enough evidence in the record justifying the High Courts companyclusi

concepts.unlisted_description: Defines 'agricultural income' as rent/revenue from agricultural land or income from agriculture, processing produce for market, or sale of produce without further processing

anchor.surface_text: defines agricultural income. Agricultural income means -  1  any rent or revenue derived from land which is used for agricultural purposes  2  any income derived form such land in the State by - agriculture, or the performance by a cultivator a receiver of rent-in-kind to render the produce raised or received by him fit to be taken to market, or the sale by a cultivator or receiver of rent-in-kind of the produce raised or received by him, in respect of which numberprocess has been performed other than a process of the nature described in sub- clause  ii .

concepts.interpretation: Excludes sale proceeds of rubber trees used for latex production after they cease yielding.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ere utilised for the purpose of deriving income in the shape of latex. There was enough evidence in the record justifying the High Courts companyclusi

concepts.unlisted_description: Statutory definition under Section 2(a) excluding tree sale proceeds as non-agricultural income

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal accepted the contention of the respondent and held that the sum of Rs. 8,532.50 representing the sale proceeds of rubber trees cut down and sold after they had become useless was not taxable as income, but was merely a capital receipt.

concepts.interpretation: Sale proceeds of rubber trees not grown for sale but for latex, felled after becoming unyielding, constitute capital receipts as trees are capital assets, not taxable as agricultural income.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: - agriculture, or the performance by a cultivator a receiver of rent-in-kind to render the produce raised or received by him fit to be taken to marke

concepts.unlisted_description: Tax principle distinguishing non-recurring proceeds from sale of capital assets (like exhausted rubber trees) from recurring revenue receipts taxable as agricultural income

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the appellant, the Tribunal stated a case to the Kerala High Court and referred the following two question of law for its opinion Whether the sale proceeds of old and unlying rubber trees grown and used for obtaining income as latex therefrom are capital receipts ? Whether the sale proceeds of unyielding trees purchased many years back as yielding trees are capital receipts ?

anchor.surface_text: There was enough evidence in the record justifying the High Courts conclusion that the rubber trees formed part of the capital assets of the respondent. Admittedly, the respondent did not grow the rubber trees for the purpose of selling them.

concepts.interpretation: Rubber trees formed part of capital assets where respondent derived income from latex, not from selling trees.

concepts.interpretation: Sale proceeds treated as capital receipt, not agricultural income.

issues.text: Whether the sale proceeds of old and unlying rubber trees grown and used for obtaining income as latex therefrom are capital receipts?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the sale proceeds of old and unlying rubber trees grown and used for obtaining income as latex therefrom are capital receipts ?

arguments.claim: The sum of Rs. 8,532.50 was in the nature of a revenue receipt and had to be included in computing the agricultural income.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contention mainly is that the sum of Rs. 8,532.50 was in the nature of a revenue receipt and had to be included in computing the agricultural income.

arguments.court_reasoning: Definition of agricultural income excludes sale proceeds of rubber trees used for latex; trees are capital assets.

arguments.claim: The sale proceeds of the rubber trees which have been planted for the purpose of yielding latex, but were cut down and sold after they had ceased to yield any further, could not be in the nature of revenue receipts.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondent is that the sale proceeds of the rubber trees which have been planted for the purpose of yielding latex, but were cut down and sold after they had ceased to yield any further, could not be in the nature of revenue receipts.

arguments.court_reasoning: Definition excludes such proceeds; trees part of capital assets not grown for sale.

arguments.claim: The sum of Rs. 8,532.50 representing the sale proceeds of rubber trees cut down and sold after they had become useless was not taxable as income, but was merely a capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated August 18, 1962, the Tribunal accepted the contention of the respondent and held that the sum of Rs. 8,532.50 representing the sale proceeds of rubber trees cut down and sold after they had become useless was not taxable as income, but was merely a capital receipt.

arguments.court_reasoning: Trees formed part of capital assets; definition does not include sale proceeds.

arguments.claim: The two questions were answered in the affirmative: sale proceeds of old and unyielding rubber trees and of unyielding trees purchased as yielding are capital receipts.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges of the Division Bench of the High Court by their judgment dated August 2, 1963, answered the two question in the affirmative and in favour of the respondent.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supported by evidence and statutory definition.

arguments.claim: The definition of agricultural income in section 2 does not include proceeds from the sale of rubber trees in an estate which were utilised for the purpose of deriving income in the shape of latex.

anchor.surface_text: The definition of agricultural income in section 2 does not include proceeds from the sale of rubber trees in an estate which were utilised for the purpose of deriving income in the shape of latex.

arguments.claim: There was enough evidence justifying the High Court's conclusion that the rubber trees formed part of the capital assets of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: There was enough evidence in the record justifying the High Courts conclusion that the rubber trees formed part of the capital assets of the respondent.

arguments.claim: The respondent did not grow the rubber trees for the purpose of selling them; income was from latex; trees became old and unyielding and were felled when no longer productive.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the respondent did not grow the rubber trees for the purpose of selling them. It was getting income from these rubber trees in the shape of latex. In course of time the rubber trees became old and unyielding. When the trees were no longer productive of latex, the respondent felled them and sold them.

arguments.claim: The Appellate Tribunal and the High Court were right in holding that the sale proceeds of these trees should be treated as capital receipt and not taxable as agricultural income.

holdings.text: The definition of agricultural income in section 2 does number include proceeds from the sale of rubber trees in an estate which were utilised for the purpose of deriving income in the shape of latex.

anchor.surface_text: The definition of agricultural income in section 2 does number include proceeds from the sale of rubber trees in an estate which were utilised for the purpose of deriving income in the shape of latex.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of Section 2(a) excludes sale proceeds of trees used to derive latex income, as it covers rent/revenue, agriculture, processing, or unprocessed produce sale, not tree sales.

holdings.text: There was enough evidence in the record justifying the High Courts companyclusion that the rubber trees formed part of the capital assets of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: There was enough evidence in the record justifying the High Courts companyclusion that the rubber trees formed part of the capital assets of the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows trees purchased producing latex, income from latex not sale, felled after unyielding, thus capital assets not trading stock.

holdings.text: The Appellate Tribunal and the High Court were, therefore, rights in holding that the sale proceeds of these trees should be treated as capital receipt and number taxable as agricultural income.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal and the High Court were, therefore, rights in holding that the sale proceeds of these trees should be treated as capital receipt and number taxable as agricultural income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combining statutory exclusion under definition and trees as capital assets, affirms lower courts that proceeds are capital not revenue/agricultural income.
